semantic_title: Hurricane Aftermath Healthcare Encounters - External Cause of Morbidity Code Usage
section_path: Section I > A. Conventions > 19. Coding for Healthcare Encounters in Hurricane Aftermath > a. Use of External Cause of Morbidity Codes

content.full_text: An external cause of morbidity code should be assigned to identify the cause of the injury(ies) incurred as a result of the hurricane. The use of external cause of morbidity codes is supplemental to the application of ICD-10-CM codes. External cause of morbidity codes are never to be recorded as a principal diagnosis (first-listed in non-inpatient settings). The appropriate injury code should be sequenced before any external cause codes. The external cause of morbidity codes capture how the injury or health condition happened (cause), the intent (unintentional or accidental; or intentional, such as suicide or assault), the place where the event occurred, the activity of the patient at the time of the event, and the person's status (e.g., civilian, military). They should not be assigned for encounters to treat hurricane victims' medical conditions when no injury, adverse effect or poisoning is involved. External cause of morbidity codes should be assigned for each encounter for care and treatment of the injury. External cause of morbidity codes may be assigned in all health care settings. For the purpose of capturing complete and accurate ICD-10-CM data in the aftermath of the hurricane, a healthcare setting should be considered as any location where medical care is provided by licensed healthcare professionals. (Evidence: pg no: 18, L70-L79)

detailed_rules.rule_text: External cause of morbidity codes are never to be recorded as a principal diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 18, L71-L72)
detailed_rules.explanation: External cause codes are always supplemental and cannot be used as the principal diagnosis in inpatient settings or first-listed diagnosis in outpatient settings (Evidence: pg no: 18, L71-L72)

detailed_rules.rule_text: The appropriate injury code should be sequenced before any external cause codes (Evidence: pg no: 18, L72)
detailed_rules.explanation: The actual injury or condition code must be listed first, followed by the external cause codes that explain how the injury occurred (Evidence: pg no: 18, L72)

detailed_rules.rule_text: External cause codes should not be assigned for encounters to treat hurricane victims' medical conditions when no injury, adverse effect or poisoning is involved (Evidence: pg no: 18, L75-L76)
detailed_rules.explanation: External cause codes are only appropriate when there is an actual injury, adverse effect, or poisoning related to the hurricane, not for general medical conditions (Evidence: pg no: 18, L75-L76)

detailed_rules.rule_text: External cause of morbidity codes should be assigned for each encounter for care and treatment of the injury (Evidence: pg no: 18, L76-L77)
detailed_rules.explanation: Every encounter that involves treatment of a hurricane-related injury should include the appropriate external cause codes (Evidence: pg no: 18, L76-L77)
